metadata.case_name: Appellants v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Local police took cognizance of a serious occurrence of rioting with murder on December 22, 1955.
Local police investigated the case, recorded evidence, and submitted a charge-sheet under ss. 147, 148, 323, 324 and 302 read with ss. 34 and 149 IPC to the magistrate.
Magistrate, following procedure in s. 207A CrPC, committed the 26 accused persons to the Court of Session, Guntur Division.
Accused filed applications in revision under ss. 435 and 439 CrPC to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh to quash the commitment order, arguing s. 207A unconstitutional.
High Court (Krishna Rao J.) dismissed the revisions on September 28, 1956, holding provisions constitutional.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.
Union of India allowed to intervene as provisions of Central Act impugned.

legal_issues.text: Constitutionality of ss. 207 and 207A CrPC introduced by Act XXVI of 1955, whether they introduce discrimination as against accused in cases on police charge-sheet violating Art. 14 Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Ss. 207 and 207A provide two separate procedures for commitment: one under s.207A for police report cases, less advantageous to accused than other procedure in Chapter XVIII.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 14 Constitution; comparisons with ss. 208(3), 208(1), 209(2), 213(2), 215, 209(1) CrPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Under s.207A, accused deprived of benefits under ss.162, 215 CrPC and ss.27, 101-106, 114(g) Evidence Act.

respondent_arguments.text: Provisions constitutional, no discrimination; changes simplify and expedite procedure.

court_reasoning.text: Amending Act XXVI of 1955 introduced changes to simplify and expedite commitment proceedings; Code always had different procedures based on gravity of offences, cognizable/non-cognizable, etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification based on whether case instituted on police report (investigated by public servant) or complaint is reasonable and has rational relation to object of speedy trial.

court_reasoning.text: No difference in trial procedure post-commitment; s.207A applies to cognizable serious offences where police duty-bound to investigate promptly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Elaborate procedure retained for complaint cases to guard against private vendetta; summary procedure under s.207A in police cases serves public interest.

court_reasoning.text: Art.14 permits reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia with rational relation to object; here, classification between police-investigated cases and complaints valid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expeditious trial benefits innocent accused; prolonging inquiry not always advantageous.

holdings.text: Ss. 207 and 207A CrPC constitutional; no violation of Art.14 as classification reasonable for speedy administration of justice.

Upheld s.197 CrPC; discretionary power not necessarily discriminatory

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned provisions for commitment procedures; police investigation and trial processes

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality before law; certificate for appeal

outcome.summary: The Court held ss. 207 and 207A CrPC constitutional, no discrimination under Art.14; appeal dismissed upholding High Court order.

key_quotes.text: The only question that arises for determination in this appeal... is the constitutionality of the provisions of ss. 207 and 207A, Code of Criminal Procedure.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: While article 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key test for Art.14 from Budhan Choudhry

key_quotes.text: There cannot be the least doubt that the Legislature has been well-advised to amend the procedure relating to commitment proceedings in cases which have been investigated by a competent police officer.
key_quotes.speaker: court
